response.answer_text: Sikhs don't worship Durga. It is prevalent among some people that Guru Gobind Singh worshipped Durga to get the strength to fight against the oppression. Actually the distortion of history has been done intentionally by many modern Indian historians, particularly covering over historical wrongs against Hindus.They believe that by correcting history, the present can be changed. They pretend that the generally cruel Mughal rule in India was benign and secular so that the account will serve to make modern Hindus and Muslims more benign and secular and help them bury the past. But the opposite is true. If a nation does not face its true history, it has no future and its present remains confused. Now we come to the point of Guru Gobind Singh and Durga. Here is the real truth about this prevalent story. The pundits with slave mentality requested Guru Gobind Singh to workship Durga to fight the Mughals. Guru showed them the real power of “Sword” to combat the atrocities of the enemy. Here is that story: A Brahmin, Pandit Keshav Das told Guru: “The goddess Durga is all powerful. He, who worships Durga, is blessed with her powers and can destroy all demonic forces”. He thought of blackmailing Guru by suggesting that he should go for worship of the goddess Durga in order to invoke her blessings for future battles. The Pandit asked Guru to hold a Havan. Their leader, Keshav Das, promised that he would reveal the goddess by reciting the “Chandi Mantra” one lakh times, but Guru would have to put up one lakh offerings. Pandit Keshav Das requested Guru to give him lot of samagri thinking that Guru will not be able to give him such a huge samagri due to its cost. But Guru ordered the sikhs to provide him as much samagri as he requires. So all the samagri was provided to the Pandit. Nine months passed but NO Durga appeared. At last, Guru asked Pandit Keshav Das the reason for Devi not appearing, to which Pandit replied to save his skin that Durga needs sacrifice of his son. Pandit said these words thinking that Guruji would refuse giving his son’s life and we will put the blame on Devi not appearing on Guruji. But Guruji smiled and replied: “Pandit, you are my beloved son, Let me give your sacrifice to Devi and when she appears, first thing I will ask her would be to receive you and your life back”. Pandit shivered with fear and started fumbling. Next minute, he said to Guru: “I need to go for nature’s call and then I will return after bath”. Guru let him go. Pandit and his followers ran away from the spot one by one and never returned. When they didn’t return after some time, Guru understood that Pandits had run away. He thought it futile to be associated with it any longer. Guru ordered Singh’s present to dump all the samagri into fire altogether. Sikhs did this and a large flame of fire rose. Guru, in his martial form stood near the fire and took out his sword and rose it. Guru looking at his sword said: “This is Chandi”. This is the real Durga which vanquished enemies in battlefield, this is the Kaalka which drinks blood of enemies and destroys them, this is the Bhagauti which protects Dharam and destroys evil”. The Sikhs hold their weddings in the morning only. Check any wedding invite on Google Images. There is never any Durga Puja at Sikh weddings. Sikhs are not into idolatry. A typical wedding begins at 9.00 AM and ends at 12.30 PM. After that a grand lunch for all attendees. Shortly the new couple leaves for the groom’s family home as the ceremony is hosted by the bride’s family. This is it. End of Wedding. Beyond this there is no ceremony that involves any deity of any kind. Raj Sharma has by given the wrong answer. He has lack of information and knowledge. I am a Sikh. I have seen innummerable Sikh weddings in my life. In Punjab, Delhi, Nasik, Kolkatta, Rajasthan, Haryana, Siliguri, Mumbai, Bangalore ( and other places ) of my cousins, relatives and family friends. All Sikh weddings have happened in the morning. And that is the ONLY ceremony. I have seen weddings of families who are not Jatt Sikhs but other orders too. They all have ONLY ONE ceremony. Moreover.. the circumambulations of Guru Granth Sahib validates the wedding. There is no need of any other presiding deity to further bless it or validate it. Not in Sikhs procedure. Once the Akaal Purukh has been asked to be witness, who else would be required? I have seen Raj Sharma’s answers to a hundred topics on the Sikhs. NOT EVEN ONE of them is completely right. I am a Sikh. He is NOT. But still he poses himself to be a knowledgeable person of my faith. He is simply not informed in his study. It is strange that not even one of his answers on Sikhism are right, but he carries on and on. He also describes other people as ‘most fanatics’, while he himself is the top fanatic I have ever seen. He believes in Taliban like one way conversation where he gives gyan and everybody else just claps for him. Only a fanatic will not allow a response. His agenda is to show that Sikhism is Hinduism. Which it is not. At random I found him saying Sikhs are called Singh because Durga is seen with a lion which is called Singha in sanskrit. That is completely wrong. Guru Gobind Singh was making an army of fighters to counter the tyranny of Aurangzeb. He wanted lions as fighters in his team. Pundits like Raj Sharma ( other pundits I honour and respect ) had seen the same DurgaDevis’ lion for centuries in prayer and worship. Not one got inspired to fight like the Sikhs did in battle. The reference is straight to the king of the jungle, not Durga Devi’s lion. In fact the Khalsa was made only because everybody was un-inspired in the way of soldiering. Durga is a revered devi in Hinduism, the Sikhs know that. On another occasion he derived the word Kaur from Kunwar or some other cryptic source. Well.. even that is incorrect. Kaur comes from ‘Kaura’ the punjabi word for bitter as a taste. It also means lioness, but thats a metaphor only I think. The idea is that if ladies were attacked while the menfolk were away in battle, they should fight back bitterly like lionesses protect their cubs. It would be better if he discusses with people who know before he posts. Or if he posts he should allow comments. So that someone may correct him. What is the logic of posting wrong stuff that may misinform readers? Well if one has an agenda.. one can force the logic.

Tl;dr Sikhs do not worship the goddess “Durga”, nor do we have jagrattas as part of our marriage ceremonies. Now addressing the first part of your question any and all Hindu influences stem from two sources in Sikh history the Dasam Granth and the control of Mahants(non-Sikh priests) over Sikh Gurdwaras. The Dasam Granth is the work of Guru Gobind Singh Ji(or his followers depending on who you ask), and throughout the holy book specifically in Chandi Di Vaar, he uses Hindu points of reference considering the subcontinent was Hindu majority, and he needed to reach the masses. Some Sikhs do not even consider the Dasam Granth to be true because of its text, and this debate has yet to have been resolved. In regards to any sort of Hindu iconography in Gurdwaras, that other answers use as “evidence” , Sikh Gurdwaras were under control of these non-Sikh priests for nearly a century. They added their own touches, and ruled these Gurdwaras like their own Kingdom, even after the movement to restore them some lingering evidence of their touches has persisted.
